subject: cisco/nexus plugin doesn't create port for router interface
commit_message:
cisco/nexus plugin doesn't create port for router interface

Fixes bug 1234826

This fix adds a "nexus_l3_enable" configuration boolean for the
Cisco Nexus plugin. When this config boolean is set to False (default),
then the Nexus switches are only used for L2 switching/segmentation, and
layer 3 functionality is deferred to the OVS subplugin / network
control node. If this config boolean is set to True, layer 3
functionality, e.g. switch virtual interfaces, are supported on
the Nexus switches. (Note that layer 3 functionality is not supported
on all versions/models Nexus switches.)

Some other things addressed with this fix:
- The l3_port_check keyword argument which is optionally passed to the
  Cisco plugin's delete_port method was not being forwarded on to the
  OVS (sub) plugin. This keyword argument needs to be forwarded to OVS
  e.g. when the delete_port is being done in the context of a
  router interface delete (whereby l3_port_check==False).
- UT test cases are added for new "nexus_l3_enable" config, which
  exercise router interface add/delete.
- The Cisco test_network_plugin.py module is refactored/reorganized
  in order to cleanly add a new router interface test class.
- The test_model_update_port_rollback test case was yielding a false
  positive result (device_owner was not being passed to self.port).

subject: VMware: Fixed upload-to-image for available volume
commit_message:
VMware: Fixed upload-to-image for available volume

Cinder generally does not allow upload-to-image operation on a volume
that is 'in-use'. This can however be over-ridden using the '--force True'
flag. The VMware driver cannot support upload-to-image when the volume is
in-use. This is a restriction for the VMware driver alone. When the user forces
an upload on a volume that is 'in-use' the Cinder api layer sets the volume
status to 'uploading' and calls into the driver code to upload. In this
scenario the VMware driver needs to fail the operation.

The current driver code here does this check wrongly by looking for volume
status of 'in-use'. Fixing this check to identify an in-use volume correctly.

Fixes bug: 1237338

subject: Avoid leaking admin-ness into threshold-oriented alarms
commit_message:
Avoid leaking admin-ness into threshold-oriented alarms

Fixes bug 1237567

Previously when an admin created a threshold-oriented alarm on
behalf of an non-admin identity, this had the effect of leaking
visibility onto statistics for resources that would not normally
be visible to the non-admin tenant.

Now we ensure that an additional implicit threshold rule query
constraint is added on the project ID of the non-admin indentity
that will ultimately own the alarm.

This is acheived by splitting the query validation from the
construction of the kwargs from the query. The addition of the
implicit query constraint to the threshold rule can then be
delayed to a later point in the dispatch path where the full
context of the alarm is known (so that we can check for the case
where the alarm is created by an admin on behalf of another tenant).

called.

subject: Optionally recalculate object ETag on GET or HEAD.
commit_message:
Optionally recalculate object ETag on GET or HEAD.

For certain categories of use-case, the way we handle object checksums
does not suffice to prove data integrity of the objects. Since we cache
the checksums in the object's metadata, the data can be silently
corrupted when the end-user tries to validate it. This silent corruption
can be ameliorated if we allow the end-user to explicitly request that
the response recalculate the hash, and we can prove we're not cheating
if we allow them to specify a nonce that we prepend to the hash
calculation.

This commit adds two optional headers to the object server's get or
head requests:

    X-Recalculate-Etag: When set, causes the object-server to
                        recalculate the ETAg before returning it to the
                        end user.
    X-Etag-Nonce: A string which is prepended to the etag recalculation.
                  When set, it implicitly acts as though
                  X-Recalculate-Etag is also set. This header has a
                  MAXIMUM length of 128 bytes. Setting this header to
                  longer than 128 Bytes raises an HTTPPreconditionFailed
                  exception.

Change-Id: I99096abe720b00a6bec4efb438aef8915877b129

subject: Avoid leaking admin-ness into threshold-oriented alarms
commit_message:
Avoid leaking admin-ness into threshold-oriented alarms

Fixes bug 1237567

Previously when an admin created a threshold-oriented alarm on
behalf of an non-admin identity, this had the effect of leaking
visibility onto statistics for resources that would not normally
be visible to the non-admin tenant.

Now we ensure that an additional implicit threshold rule query
constraint is added on the project ID of the non-admin indentity
that will ultimately own the alarm.

This is acheived by splitting the query validation from the
construction of the kwargs from the query. The addition of the
implicit query constraint to the threshold rule can then be
delayed to a later point in the dispatch path where the full
context of the alarm is known (so that we can check for the case
where the alarm is created by an admin on behalf of another tenant).
